math201/lecture1/lecture1.html.title: Lecture 1
math201/lecture1/lecture1.html.body:
Differential Equations

In Newton's second law

t is independent variable
x is dependent variable

Difference between ODE and PDE:

ODE's unknown function depends on only one independent varibale while the one of PDE depends on more than one independent varibale

Example of PDE and partial derivatives

unknown function f(x,y)f(x,y)f(x,y) has two independent variable xxx and yyy
partial derivative
first order - ∂f∂x\frac{\partial f}{\partial x}​∂x​​∂f​​ and ∂f∂y\frac{\partial f}{\partial y}​∂y​​∂f​​
second order - ∂2f∂x2\frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x^2}​∂x​2​​​​∂​2​​f​​, ∂2f∂y2\frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial y^2}​∂y​2​​​​∂​2​​f​​ and ∂2f∂x∂y\frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x\partial y}​∂x∂y​​∂​2​​f​​ 



Linear DEs

Solutions of DEs and Initial Value Problems

General Solution has to include all solution of given DE
Initial condition and boundary condition are called side conditions 
Rule of Thumb:

the order of a DE === number of side conditions of DE

Examples of IVP and BVP

IVP - given value at same ttt where t=0t = 0t=0

{2x′′=x(t)x(0)=1x′(0)=2\begin{cases}
2x^{''} = x(t) \\
x(0) = 1 \\
x^{'}(0) = 2
\end{cases}​⎩​⎪​⎨​⎪​⎧​​​2x​​′′​​​​=x(t)​x(0)=1​x​​′​​​​(0)=2​​

BVP - given value at different ttt

{2x′′=x(t)x(0)=1x(1)=2\begin{cases}
2x^{''} = x(t) \\
x(0) = 1 \\
x(1) = 2
\end{cases}​⎩​⎪​⎨​⎪​⎧​​​2x​​′′​​​​=x(t)​x(0)=1​x(1)=2​​
The Simplest DEs: Antiderivatives

Another way to write the general solution using a definite integral, where y(t0)y(t_0)y(t​0​​) is same as CCC
y(t)−y(t0)=∫t0tg(s)dsy(t) - y(t_0) = \int_{t_0}^{t} g(s)dsy(t)−y(t​0​​)=∫​t​0​​​t​​g(s)ds
And y(t0)=y0y(t_0) = y_0y(t​0​​)=y​0​​ is a given inital condition
Example

First-order linear ODEs

The integrating factor method

Side Note:
μ=e∫p(t)dt \mu = e^{\int p(t)dt}μ=e​∫p(t)dt​​
μ(y′(t)+p(t)y(t)=μg(t) \mu (y^{'}(t) + p(t)y(t) = \mu g(t) μ(y​​′​​​​(t)+p(t)y(t)=μg(t)
μy′(t)+μp(t)y(t)=μg(t) \mu y^{'}(t) + \mu p(t)y(t) = \mu g(t)μy​​′​​​​(t)+μp(t)y(t)=μg(t)
Taking derivate of integral of a function equals to the function itself
∵μ′=ddte∫p(t)dt=p(t)e∫p(t)dt \because \mu^{'} = \frac{d}{dt} e^{\int p(t)dt} = p(t) e^{\int p(t)dt}∵μ​​′​​​​=​dt​​d​​e​∫p(t)dt​​=p(t)e​∫p(t)dt​​
∴μy′(t)+μ′y(t)=μg(t) \therefore \mu y^{'}(t) + \mu^{'}y(t) = \mu g(t) ∴μy​​′​​​​(t)+μ​​′​​​​y(t)=μg(t)
by mupltiplication
ddt(μ(t)y(t))=μg(t) \frac{d}{dt}(\mu (t) y(t)) = \mu g(t)​dt​​d​​(μ(t)y(t))=μg(t)

math209/lecture2/lecture2.html.title: Lecture 2
math209/lecture2/lecture2.html.body:
Lecture 2
Limits
Definition (not required)


Limit of f(x,y)f(x,y)f(x,y) as (x,y)(x,y)(x,y) approaching (a,b)(a,b)(a,b) equals to number LLL where f(x,y)f(x,y)f(x,y) is being as close as number LLL

(x−a)2+(y−b)2→\sqrt {(x-a)^2+(y-b)^2} \rightarrow√​(x−a)​2​​+(y−b)​2​​​​​→ in 2D is a circle

δ→\delta \rightarrowδ→ radius of the circle




If value for point (x,y)(x,y)(x,y) is in domain DDD and is within a circle whose origin is (a,b)(a,b)(a,b) has a radius δ\deltaδ, point falls in interval of L−ϵL - \epsilonL−ϵ and L+ϵL + \epsilonL+ϵ

The disntance of f(x,y)−Lf(x,y) - Lf(x,y)−L is always smaller than ϵ\epsilonϵ


Side Note:
∣f(x,y)−L∣ϵ|f(x,y) - L| ∣f(x,y)−L∣ϵ

−(f(x,y)−L)ϵ-(f(x,y) - L) −(f(x,y)−L)ϵ and f(x,y)−Lϵf(x,y) - L f(x,y)−Lϵ

L−ϵf(x,y)L+ϵL - \epsilon L−ϵf(x,y)L+ϵ

Remark:

∣f(x,y)−L∣|f(x,y) - L|∣f(x,y)−L∣ only describe the distance between number f(x,y) and L


Example (limit do not exist)
General Solution:

path approach method
choose a function that represent a curve or path (line, parabola, etc.)
curve / path should cross point (a,b)(a,b)(a,b)
choose the curve / path that is relatively simple to approach (a,b)(a,b)(a,b)



Example 1:


Solution


Let y
y=kxy = kxy=kx

then replace yyy in f(x,y)f(x,y)f(x,y) with kxkxkx
f(x,y)=f(x,kx)=...=k21+k4x2xf(x,y) = f(x,kx) = ... = \frac {k^2}{1+k^4x^2}xf(x,y)=f(x,kx)=...=​1+k​4​​x​2​​​​k​2​​​​x

calculate the limit as x approach to 000 
limx→0f(x,kx)\lim\limits_{x \to 0}f(x,kx)​x→0​lim​​f(x,kx) = 0

Let x
x=y2x = y^2x=y​2​​ 

then
f(x,y)=f(y2,y)=...=12f(x,y) = f(y^2, y) = ... = \frac {1}{2}f(x,y)=f(y​2​​,y)=...=​2​​1​​

∵12≠0\because \frac {1}{2} \neq 0∵​2​​1​​≠0 

∴\therefore∴ Limit D.N.E by definition

Examples (limit do exist)
General Solution:

use path approach method to determine whether if the limit exist
if the limit exist and can be calculated, the limit from calculation is "supspect limit"

prove the supspect limit: use either ϵ δ\epsilon ~ \deltaϵ δ definition or Squeeze theorm


Example 1 :




Solution



apply Squeeze Th.
take a function similared to f(x,y)f(x,y)f(x,y) (omit the x2x^2x​2​​ term in the bottom)
compare with the original function



Side Note:

abs. value of term with even degree is same as the original term


Continuity

Notes (not a single cond.):

f(a,b)f(a,b)f(a,b) must exist, that is, (a,b)∈Df(a,b) \in D_f(a,b)∈D​f​​ (domain)
lim(x,y)→(a,b)\lim\limits_{(x,y) \to (a,b)}​(x,y)→(a,b)​lim​​ must exist
If both exist, they must be equal
